case_name: East Indian Railways clerk v. Union of India

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 283 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 283 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated November 20, 1958 of the Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in First Civil Appeal No. 3 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated, November 20, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  in First Civil Appeal No. 3 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant was a clerk in the service of the East Indian Railways.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, a clerk in the service of the East Indian Railways was companypulsorily retired from service with effect from June 30, 1948,

facts.text: Appellant was compulsorily retired from service with effect from June 30, 1948 on attaining the age of 55 years.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, a clerk in the service of the East Indian Railways was companypulsorily retired from service with effect from June 30, 1948, on attaining the age of 55 years.

facts.text: Appellant's prayer for further retention in service under Rule 2046/2 of the Railway Establishment Code was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: His prayer for further retention in service on the ground that he was entitled to be retained under Rule 2046/2 of the Railway Establishment Code having been rejected he brought the suit

facts.text: Appellant brought suit in the court of the Civil Judge, Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: he brought the suit which has given rise to this appeal in the companyrt of the Civil Judge, Lucknow, alleging that he was entitled to be retained under the above rule,

facts.text: Appellant alleged he was entitled to be retained under Rule 2046/2 and the order of compulsory retirement was void.

anchor.surface_text: alleging that he was entitled to be retained under the above rule, and the order for companypulsory retirement-on attaining the age of 55 years was. void and inoperative in law.

facts.text: Appellant prayed for declaratory decree that retirement order was illegal and void, and for arrears of pay assuming continued service.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly prayed for a declaratory decree that the order of his companypulsory retirement was illegal and void and for a money decree for, arrears of pay on the basis that he had companytinued in service.

facts.text: Main defence was denial of appellant's right to be retained in service under the rules.

anchor.surface_text: The main defence was a denial of his right to be retained in service under the rules.

facts.text: Trial Court accepted plaintiff's contention on effect of the rule, granted declaration and decreed money claim in part.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court accepted the plaintiffs companytention as regards the effect of the rule, gave him a declaration as prayed for and also decreed the claim for money in part.

facts.text: High Court on appeal held Rule 2046 gave no right to continue beyond 55, allowed appeal and dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the High Court took a different view of Rule 2046 and held that that rule gave the plaintiff numberright to companytinue in service beyond the age of 55 years. The High Court therefore allowed the appeal. and dismissed the plaintiffs suit.

facts.text: Present appeal preferred on certificate granted by High Court under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision the plaintiff has preferred the present appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 133 1   c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Plaintiff's case that he continued to be efficient after 55 years not disputed by respondent Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to mention that the plaintiffs case that he companytinued to be efficient even after attaining the age of 55 years has number been disputed by the respondent, the Union of India.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 16, 1961 by Das Gupta J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAs GUPTA, J.-

facts.text: Railway Board notification dated October 19, 1948 for dealing with retirement cases of ministerial servants under Rule 2046(2)(a).

anchor.surface_text: It was next urged by Mr. Aggarwal, though faintly, that the numberification of the Railway Board dated October 19, 1948, and the further numberification dated April 15, 1952,

facts.text: Railway Board notification dated April 15, 1952 providing special treatment for ministerial servants retired under Rule 2046(2)(a) after September 8, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and the further numberification dated April 15, 1952, as a result of which ministerial servants who were retired under rule 2046 2  a  before attaining the age of 60 after September 8, 1948, have been given special treatment

facts.text: Government of India decision on September 8, 1948 that non-ministerial servants aged 55-60 should be given opportunity to show cause against retirement.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on September 8, 1948, the Government of India came to a decision that numberministerial Government servant to whom the fundamental rule 56 b  i  applied and who has attained the age of 55 years but has number attained the age of 60 years companyld be required to retire from service unless he has been given a reasonable opportunity to show cause against the proposed retirement

facts.text: Appellant retired before September 8, 1948, so not given special treatment under 1952 notification.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant... retired ... June 30, 1948

facts.text: Appeal dismissed, no order as to costs as appellant is a pauper.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed. There will be numberorder as to companyts, as the appellant is a pauper.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Rule 2046(2)(a) gave no right to ministerial servant to continue till 60 even if efficient.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrect interpretation of Rule 2046  2   a  of the companye, in our opinion, is that a railway ministerial servant falling within this clause may be companypulsorily retired on attaining the age of 55 but when the servant is between the age of 55 and 60 the appropriate authority has the option to companytinue him in service,
under Art. 133 1   c  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Use of conjunction 'but' in Rule 2046(2)(a) cuts down right to retire at 55 to cases of inefficiency, entitling efficient servant to continue till 60

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it is urged that the very use of the conjunction but is for the definite purpose of the cutting down of the right conferred by the first clause and that the effect of the second clause is that the right to require the Government servant to retire at 55 is limited only to cases where he does not retain his efficiency

arguments.court_reasoning: Language reasonably clear that first part not limited by second; 'should ordinarily' indicates option not obligation

arguments.claim: Rule 2046(2)(a) more favourable to cl(a) servants: retention after 55 ordinary if efficient till 60, unlike cl(b) or non-ministerial where exceptional

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that the rule as regards compulsory retirement is more favourable to ministerial servants who fall within cl. a of rule 2046/2 than those who fall under cl. b of the same rule or railway servants who are not ministerial servants. For whereas in the case of these...

arguments.claim: Language of rule indicates authority has right to retire at 55 not cut down by second clause; gives option to retain if efficient till 60 but not bound

anchor.surface_text: We are constrained to say that the language used in this rule is unnecessarily involved but at the same time it is reasonably clear that the defect in the language creates no doubt as regards the intention of the rule-making authority. That intention, in our opinion, is that the right conferred by the first part is not in any way limited

arguments.claim: 'Should ordinarily be retained' means in large majority of cases but not invariably; authority not bound to retain even if efficient

anchor.surface_text: This intention is made even more clear and beyond doubt by the use of the word ordinarily. Ordinarily means in the large majority of cases but not invariably. This itself emphasises the fact that the appropriate authority is not bound to retain the servant after he attains the age of 55 even if he continues to be efficient.

arguments.claim: Correct interpretation: may be retired at 55; between 55-60 option to continue if efficient but not bound

anchor.surface_text: The correct interpretation of Rule 2046 2 a of the Code, in our opinion, is that a railway ministerial servant falling within this clause may be compulsorily retired on attaining the age of 55 but when the servant is between the age of 55 and 60 the appropriate authority has the option to continue him in service,

arguments.claim: Interpretation adopted by several High Courts: Basant Kumar Pal, Kishan Dayal, Raghunath Narain Mathur

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that this interpretation of the rule has been adopted by several High Courts in India Basant Kumar Pal v. The Chief Electrical Engineer Kishan Dayal v. General Manager, Northern Railway and Raghunath Narain Mathur v. Union of India.

arguments.claim: Classification of servants retired before/after Sep 8 1948 reasonable, no violation of Art 14

anchor.surface_text: The decision that nothing should be done as regards those who had already retired on that date cannot be said to have been arbitrarily made. The formation of a different class of those who retired after September 8, 1948, from those who had retired before that date on which the decision was taken is a reasonable classification

holdings.text: We therefore hold that the High Court was right in holding that this rule gave the plaintiff no right to continue in service beyond the age of 55

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the High Court was right in holding that this rule gave the plaintiff numberright to companytinue in service beyond the age of 55.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation of Rule 2046(2)(a): first clause allows retirement at 55, second provides option not obligation to retain efficient servant till 60 as indicated by 'but should ordinarily'; supported by High Court precedents

holdings.text: The formation of a different class of those who retired after September 8, 1948, from those who had retired before that date on which the decision was taken is a reasonable classification and does not offend Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The formation of a different class of those who retired after September 8, 1948, from those who had retired before that date on which the decision was taken is a reasonable classification and does number offend Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification based on date of Government policy change on Sep 8 1948 requiring show cause opportunity before retirement has rational nexus to administrative decision not to reopen pre-existing retirements

holdings.text: The correct interpretation of Rule 2046 2 a of the Code, in our opinion, is that a railway ministerial servant falling within this clause may be compulsorily retired on attaining the age of 55 but when the servant is between the age of 55 and 60 the appropriate authority has the option to continue him in service, subject to the condition that the servant continues to be efficient but the authority is not bound to retain him even if a servant continues to be efficient

precedents.citation: Jai Ram v. Union of India  1

anchor.surface_text: Jai Ram v. Union of India  1 when speaking for the Court as regards this rule his Lordship said- We think it is a possible view to take upon the language of this rule that a ministerial servant coming within the purview has normally the right to be retained in service till he reaches the age of 60.

precedents.case_name: Jai Ram v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: possible view that a ministerial servant coming within the purview of Rule 2046/2(a) has normally the right to be retained in service till the age of 60 if he continues to be efficient
precedents.cited_holding: We think it is a possible view to take upon the language of this rule that a ministerial servant coming within the purview has normally the right to be retained in service till he reaches the age of 60. This is conditional undoubtedly upon his continuing to be efficient. We may assume therefore for purposes of this case that the plaintiff had the right to continue in service till 60 and could not be retired before that except on the ground of inefficiency.

precedents.citation: Basant Kumar Pal v. The Chief Electrical Engineer
